revision.text: ==[[Cyclic Multiverse Theory]] is on [[WB:VFD|Votes for deletion]]== Hello Kmarinas86, welcome to Wikibooks! I suggest that you go read [[Wikibooks:What is Wikibooks]] and learn what this project is about. Then you can [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|become a contributor]]. I noticed that your first contribution, [[Cyclic Multiverse Theory]], is now on [[Wikibooks:Votes for deletion]]. It seems that it had [[wikipedia:Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Cyclic Multiverse Theory|faced deletion on Wikipedia]], and some Wikipedia users had unfortunately suggested moving the page to Wikibooks. We have [[Wikibooks:What is Wikibooks#Wikibooks is not a place to publish original works|rules against original research]], which is what your contribution seems to be. There is almost certainly some wiki that can take original-research contributions. I wonder if [[wikinfo:Main Page|Wikinfo]] would take it. They are similar to Wikipedia, but have [[wikinfo:Wikinfo:About/Comparisons to Wikipedia|several significant differences]]. I do not contribute to Wikinfo (though I read it sometimes) so I am not immediately sure if it is an appropriate place. --[[User:Kernigh|Kernigh]] 17:29, 22 October 2005 (UTC) Sorry for putting this on the wrong page --[[User:Kernigh|Kernigh]] 17:58, 22 October 2005 (UTC) ==Image copyright problem with [[:Image:La Méditation Sensuelle.gif]]== Thanks for uploading [[:Image:La Méditation Sensuelle.gif]]. The [[w:Wikimedia Foundation|Wikimedia Foundation]] is very careful about the images included in Wikibooks because of [[w:United States copyright law|copyright law]], and requires that we maintain a strict [[Wikibooks:Copyright|copyright policy]]. The image that may soon be deleted unless we can determine the copyright holder and status. The copyright holder is usually the creator, the creator's employer, or the last person who was transferred ownership rights. Copyright information on images is signified using copyright templates. The three basic license types on Wikibooks are [[w:open content|open content]], [[w:public domain|public domain]], and [[w:fair use|fair use]]. Find the appropriate template in [[Wikibooks:Image copyright tags]] and place it on the image page like this: {{TemplateName}}. Please signify the copyright information on any other images you have uploaded or will upload. Remember that images without this important information or giving false information can be deleted by an administrator. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask another Wikibookian at the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|help desk]]. Thank you. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 23:09, 30 August 2007 (UTC) :Please note that Commons rules apply only on Commons. We have our own rules about what images are allowed; this one seems to be a copyright violation, and has been listed as such. Please check the rest of your images and ensure that they all have appropriate license information. You may want to try uploading the images to Commons if you think their rules will allow it. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 23:09, 30 August 2007 (UTC) == [[Sensual Meditation]] has been nominated for deletion == Please comment and vote at [[WB:VFD#Sensual Meditation]]. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 15:29, 11 September 2007 (UTC) :It was [[WB:DP#Speedy deletions|deleted without discussion]]. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 17:42, 11 September 2007 (UTC)

Visual Basic has a traditional set of built in string operations. Unlike many languages Visual Basic strings are always [[w:Unicode|Unicode]] so they can hold any character. They are also always dynamically allocated and are of almost unlimited length (theoretically up to about 2^31 characters, about 2000 million).
Note that Unicode uses more than one byte to represent each character. As far as VB is concerned Unicode characters are two bytes which gives 2^16 or 65536 possible values. This is enough even for Chinese, Japanase and Korean character sets (''CJK''). In fact Unicode defines 17 planes each of which has room for 2^16 code points but VB (and Windows) uses only the [[w:Basic Multilingual Plane|Basic Multilingual Plane]] (''BMP'').
See [http://web.archive.org/web/20080626021549/http://www.romanpress.com/Articles/Strings_R/Strings.htm What Are VB Strings?] for a concise explanation of the internal workings of Visual Basic Classic strings.
==[[../Built In String Functions|Built In String Functions]]== Visual Basic provides a reasonable set of traditional functions for manipulating and searching strings. These functions are usually all that is needed for most programs that are not primarily concerned with text processing.
==[[../Regular Expressions|Regular Expressions]]== A regular expression is a character string in which some characters have special meanings. Such a string can be used to search for substrings in another string in much more sophisticated ways than the built in InStr function.
For example this expression:
"(dog|cat)"
will match either 'dog' or 'cat'.
Visual Basic has no built in regular expression functions, but these are available in the VBScript regular expression library. If your program does a lot of text processing ''regular expressions'' are definitely worth learning even though they may seem intimidating at the start. In practice most programmers find that the more arcane expressions are rarely used and the same idioms are recycled over and over so there is really not as much to learn as it at first appears.
{{VBClassicNav1|Loops|Built In String Functions}}

revision.text:
*Takedowns **Ankle pick **Near ankle trip **Fireman's carry **Lateral drop **Duck under **Ankle sweep **Super duck *Setups **Arm Drag **Post **Counter-Attack *Tie-Ups **2 on 1 or Russian tie **Under, Over **Single and Double Underhooks **Single and Double Overhooks
Fireman's carry: Begin by tying up with inside control. Next you will need to do a draw-in step (take a step backwards to draw the opponent in to you). As they step in towards you, drop to your left knee while holding on to the inside control with your left hand(DO NOT LET GO). Take your right arm and wrap it around the opponents right leg. Drop your left shoulder to the mat and sit through to a headlock.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

==not extensions== Lots of this stuff made it into the 1999 C standard or is available via the optimizer. The standard C way to do a rotation is to use shifting, masking, and oring. A good compiler, like gcc, will use a rotate instruction for this. Variable length array stuff is in the 1999 standard. [[User:AlbertCahalan|AlbertCahalan]] 18:54, 22 October 2005 (UTC)
: Yes. Should we spell out exactly how to do that here, or just link to other sections of this book for more details? [[C Programming/Further math#shift and rotate]] discusses the rotate instruction. [[Talk:C Programming/Weaknesses of C]] briefly mentions the "variable length array" syntax and the "flexible array member" syntax. Where in this book is the right place to fully explain how to use them? --[[User:DavidCary|DavidCary]] ([[User talk:DavidCary|talk]]) 15:44, 3 November 2008 (UTC)

revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/204.234.203.42|204.234.203.42]] ([[User talk:204.234.203.42|talk]]) to last version by Avicennasis
revision.text:
*Top **Tilts ***Cheap Tilt ***Ball and Chain Tilt ***tight waist tilt **Stacks **Other ***Ball and Chain ***1/4,3/4,Power, Nelson *Riding **Legs **Western **Arm Bars
---- Tight waist tilt-get a tight waist and drive your opponent at a 11 o'clock angle(if you have the tight waist in your right hand)while driving pull the waist and secure an arm with your other arm and get into a tight near fall position.not good for pinning but great for getting quick easy points
'''Riding Legs'''
''The key to riding legs is constantly repositioning your hips!'' When you ride legs, or "throw legs in" you need to have excellent balance. This will be explained starting from referees position, on the left side.
1- Take your left leg and kick it between your opponents left arm and left leg, then rap it around his left leg.
2-Using your Right Leg, do what is called a "Dig Shin." where you put your foot under your opponents shin and raise itup to keep your opponent off balance. It also acts like an emergency brake if you get thrown.
3- ALWAYS GRAB HOLD OF SOMETHING WHEN RIDING LEGS! GRAB HIS ARM OR LEG, THROW IN A HALF, ANYTHING!
Now there are a couple moves you can work from here...
*Guillotine One of the best/hardest moves in wrestling. With your left leg in, use your left arm to hook his right arm. Then grab his right wrist with your right hand. Lift the arm just high enough to where you can duck your head under it, and pop it up on the other side of the arm. Release his arm with your left arm but stay on th wrist with your right. Arch back SLOWLY, while SLOWLY reaching your left arm towards his head. Once you have his head and he is on his back, let go of his wrist and connect both hands around his head. Pull his head toward you and arch into him with your hips, HARD. Stand by for the win.
*Banana Split A less complicated move than the guillotine. With the left leg in, reach your left arm to the inside of his right leg. Connect your right hand behind the leg with your left. Then arch backwards and roll him onto his back. Arch into him as hard as possible.
*Inverted Spladle This move is dangerous in the higher weights, so let the little guys stick to this one (103-140) With the left leg in, reach with your RIGHT arm inside of the right leg. Connect with your left hand in FRONT of the right leg. Roll to his back. If you lock this up correctly, and hang on tight, there is practically no way to lose, unless you are losing by 4 points and you run out of time for the pin.
*Power Half This is a pretty basic move. all you have to do is get both of your legs in then get in a half and hook it up with your other hand then begin powering them over.
*Helicopter This is a simple move where you throw the leg that is not hooked to the other side of the opponents body like your leg is the arm of a helicopter then when the opponent falls to his hip cross face him to the mat.(swing your leg as hard as possible)

revision.comment: a ref is used to prove the content, not to something "linked". Also, as this is a cookbook linking ingredient pages to external recipes is not a good idea. the links should be internal to WB
revision.text:
{{fruit}} [[Image:Artocarpus heterophyllus fruits at tree.jpg|thumb|Jackfruit]]
The '''jackfruit''' is a very large fruit from trees native to south-western [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]] and [[Cookbook:Sri Lanka|Sri Lanka]]. Jackfruit can be up to 90cm long, 50cm in diameter, and weight up to 36kg. The taste is similar to that of [[Cookbook:Pineapple|pineapple]], but milder and less juicy. It is popular throughout [[Cookbook:South Asian cuisines|South Asia]] and [[Cookbook:Southeast Asian cuisines|South-east Asia]].
Jackfruit can be eaten as a fresh fruit, both ripe and unripe. It is also often combined into cooked meals, both sweet and savoury. Jackfruit can be bought in cans, and as dried pieces.
{{Wikipedia|Jackfruit}} [[Category:Jackfruit recipes|*]]
===Young fruit=== The young fruit is called ''Polos'' in Sri Lanka. It is a dish with spices to replace meat curries in Sri Lankan cuisine. The skin of unripe (young) jack fruit must be pared first and discarded and then the whole fruit can be chopped into edible portions and cooked to be eaten. The raw young fruit is not edible. Young jackfruit has a mild flavour and distinctive poultry like texture. The cuisines of India,Nepal,Bangladesh,Sri Lanka,Indonesia,Cambodia, and Vietnam use cooked young jackfruit. In Indonesia, young jackfruit is eaten as gudeg. In many cultures, jackfruit is boiled and used in curries as a staple food. [[Image:Jackfruit chips.jpg|thumb||upright|Jackfruit chips]]
===Ripe fruit=== Ripe jackfruit is naturally sweet with subtle flavouring. It can be used to make a variety of dishes including custards, cakes, halo-halo and more. Ripe jackruit arils are sometimes seeded, fried and sold as jackfruit chips.
==External links== *[http://www.jackfruitrecipes.info Jackfruit Recipes | Easy Jackfruit Recipe Collection]

: I have to respectfully disagree with your oppinion that the single page at [[Google_Services_And_Products/Gmail]] is more organised than [[Gmail]]. I suggest that we merge the content to this book and link here. We could place this book under [[Google_Services_And_Products]] but, frankly, I don't see the need for it. : An argument could be made to place it under a book on free email services. Since there are multiple ways of categorising it, but it doesn't depend on any other modules, I think it's better to keep things seperate and link books on related topics. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 18:42, 12 June 2008 (UTC)
== Delete the old name convention redirects ==
The argument against is that there is no real need and one shouldn't delete pages that might have links pointing to them from outside Wikibooks. The argument for is that deleting these helps clear up the [[Special:AllPages]] indices and this wikibook is hardly such a big player that anyone will have links dating back a couple of years to the pages here. Anyone against? --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 19:06, 12 June 2008 (UTC)

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|6|prep: 10 minutes
resting: 30 minutes
cooking: ~5 minutes|2||250 Cal each (if cooked in oil, 700 Cal each)}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Native American cuisine|Native American Cuisine]] This is a traditional [[Cookbook:Native American cuisine|Native American]] [[cookbook:flatbread|flatbread]] usually made on an open fire or a [[Cookbook:Barbecue|barbecue]], or fried in a pan of hot oil over a stove top. This recipe uses modern techniques and tools. Fry bread is best served hot, topped with melted margarine, [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] or agave nectar, berry [[Cookbook:Jam|jam]], or [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] and [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]]. ==Ingredients== * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tsp|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] (alternatively and for a healthier end product, you can substitute either 1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] of plain yogurt, or a 1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] of soured milk as a leavening agent instead of baking powder, but add 2 hours to the rest time for the dough, and the dough must be left somewhere warm. You can include the baking powder as well to get a very puffy version of frybread as an optional ingredient) * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|T]] [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] (alternatively, you can use mayonaise in place of shortening for a crispy, crunchier texture) * 2/3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] hot water (if using yogurt or soured milk for leavening, use a 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] of water instead) ==Procedure== # Mix flour, baking powder (or yogurt or soured milk) and salt in a bowl. # Use a [[Cookbook:Pastry Blender|pastry blender]] (or two butter knives) to cut the shortening (or mayonaise) into the flour. # Add the hot water and mix until the water is incorporated. # Turn out the dough on a lightly floured board. # Knead the dough until it is soft and smooth. # Wrap the dough in plastic and let the dough rest for 30 minutes (if using yogurt or soured milk as a leavening agent, let the dough rest for 2 hours). # Divide the dough into 6 pieces, roll each into a ball, and roll into flat disks with a [[Cookbook:Rolling Pin|rolling pin]]. # Brush one side of each disk with melted margarine and place on a barbecue over a [[Cookbook:Barbecuing#.22Mississippi.22_Method|3 Mississippi]] fire (you can also fry the dough in hot oil over a stovetop. The dough cooks rapidly and will brown in about 12 seconds and must be turned over to allow the opposite side to brown, then be removed from the oil and placed sideways into a colander or large bowl lined with paper towels to allow the oil to drain off the finished product). # Brush the opposing side of the bread with margarine and flip the bread on the barbecue. # Cook until both sides are golden brown. Serve hot. [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Grilled recipes]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Native American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
